modules.title: Alternative Investment Features, Methods, and Structures

concepts.title: Alt Investment Categories
concepts.desc: Private capital (PE, VC), Real assets (real estate, infrastructure, natural resources), Hedge funds, Digital assets.

concepts.title: Investment Methods
concepts.desc: Fund investment (LP in fund), Co-investment (alongside GP), Direct investment (own the asset directly).

concepts.title: Limited Partnership Structure
concepts.desc: GP: manages fund, has unlimited liability. LPs: passive investors, limited liability. Management fee + performance fee.

concepts.title: Compensation: 2 and 20
concepts.desc: Typical: 2% management fee (on committed/invested capital) + 20% performance fee (carried interest) above hurdle rate.

concepts.title: Key Features
concepts.desc: Illiquidity, long time horizons, complex strategies, less regulation, higher fees, potentially higher returns.

formulas.name: Management Fee
formulas.formula: Mgmt Fee = Fee Rate √ó AUM (or committed capital)

formulas.name: Performance Fee
formulas.formula: Perf Fee = Incentive Rate √ó max(0, Return - Hurdle Rate)

formulas.name: Net Return to LP
formulas.formula: Net Return = Gross Return - Mgmt Fee - Performance Fee

decisions.question: Fund vs Co-investment vs Direct?
use: Fund: diversification, professional management, access to deals
Co-investment: lower fees, more control, specific deal selection
Direct: full control, no GP fees, requires significant expertise
avoid: Direct investment without sufficient expertise and resources

pitfalls: Committed capital: you owe the full amount even if not yet called
High-water mark: performance fee only on NEW profits (protects investors from paying fees twice)
Hurdle rate: minimum return before GP earns carried interest
Survivorship bias: failed funds drop from databases, inflating reported returns

questions.question: A high-water mark provision protects investors by:
options: Ensuring the GP only earns performance fees on new profits above previous peaks
questions.explanation: The high-water mark ensures the GP earns carried interest only on profits that exceed the highest previous NAV, preventing double-dipping on the same gains.

questions.question: In a typical PE fund structure, the general partner:
options: Manages the fund and has unlimited liability
questions.explanation: The GP actively manages investments, makes decisions, and bears unlimited liability. LPs are passive with limited liability.

questions.question: Survivorship bias in hedge fund databases causes:
questions.explanation: Failed/closed funds drop out of databases, leaving only survivors. This inflates average reported returns upward.

concepts.title: Venture Capital
concepts.desc: Early-stage funding: seed, Series A/B/C. High risk, high return. J-curve: negative returns early, positive later.

concepts.title: Leveraged Buyouts (LBOs)
concepts.desc: Acquire company using significant debt. Improve operations, sell for profit. Target: stable cash flows, undervalued assets.

concepts.title: Private Debt
concepts.desc: Direct lending, mezzanine financing, distressed debt. Higher yields than public bonds. Less liquid.

concepts.title: Exit Strategies
concepts.desc: IPO, sale to strategic buyer, secondary sale, recapitalization. Time horizon typically 5-10 years.

pitfalls: J-curve: PE funds show negative returns in early years (fees and investments made before returns)
Valuation challenges: no market prices for private assets
Vintage year effects: fund performance depends heavily on market conditions at entry/exit

questions.question: The J-curve in private equity refers to:
options: Initial negative returns followed by positive returns over time
Declining returns over the fund's life
The shape of the yield curve
questions.explanation: The J-curve shows negative returns in early years (management fees and write-downs) before investments mature and generate positive returns.

questions.question: An LBO target company ideally has:
options: High growth and negative cash flows
Stable cash flows and undervalued assets
questions.explanation: LBOs use significant leverage, so target companies need stable cash flows to service debt, and undervalued assets provide upside potential.

modules.title: Real Estate, Infrastructure, and Hedge Funds

concepts.title: Real Estate Investment
concepts.desc: Direct: own property. Indirect: REITs, funds. Income + appreciation. Cap rate = NOI/Property value.

concepts.title: REITs
concepts.desc: Real Estate Investment Trusts: traded like stocks. Must distribute 90%+ of income. Liquid exposure to real estate.

concepts.title: Infrastructure
concepts.desc: Essential services: utilities, transport, telecom. Long-lived assets, regulated returns, inflation protection.

concepts.title: Hedge Fund Strategies
concepts.desc: Equity L/S, Event-driven, Relative value, Global macro. Absolute return objective. Use leverage and short-selling.

concepts.title: Hedge Fund Features
concepts.desc: Lock-up periods, redemption notice, gates, side pockets. Less liquid than mutual funds. Limited regulation.

formulas.name: Value from Cap Rate
formulas.where: Lower cap rate = higher value (lower risk)

decisions.question: Direct vs REIT real estate investment?
use: Direct: full control, tax benefits, higher returns potential
REITs: liquidity, diversification, professional management, lower minimum
avoid: Direct investment without property management expertise

pitfalls: Cap rate is a single-year measure ‚Äî doesn't capture growth or financing
REITs are correlated with equities in short term but with real estate in long term
Hedge fund returns are affected by survivorship, backfill, and self-reporting biases

A lock-up period for a hedge fund:
options: Prevents investors from withdrawing capital for a specified period
questions.explanation: Lock-up periods restrict investor redemptions for a set time (often 1-2 years), giving the manager time to implement strategies.
